awd_titl_txt: Year-Long Faculty Learning Community on the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning for Linguists
awd_abstract_narration:
This project supports a year-long Faculty Learning Community (FLC) on the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL) for linguists from across the United States. The primary objective is to increase the availability and quality of SoTL-related materials in the field of linguistics, leading to better pedagogical outcomes in K-12 and higher education, following many other STEM fields such as Chemistry, Engineering, and Psychology. The project will result in the training of a cohort of linguists who will promote inclusivity, mentoring, networking, and pedagogical development. This work has the potential to create a network of linguistics scholars with expertise on teaching and learning, which will benefit the field of Linguistics, as well as the academe. 

The group will meet online bi-weekly throughout the 2019-2020 academic year and will have two in-person workshops. The FLC will be facilitated by the two Associate Editors of the Teaching Linguistics section of Language, the flagship journal of the Linguistic Society of America (LSA). Participants in the FLC will design a SoTL project to be carried out in one of their courses in the Spring 2020 term, and will present on their preliminary findings at the May workshop. During the workshop, participants will also consult with their peers, as well as the facilitators and project consultants, to determine best practices in disseminating their scholarship, and to create a strategy for spreading SoTL to the rest of the LSA membership, beginning with plans for the 2021 annual meeting.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This grant implemented a disciplinary inter-institutional Faculty Learning Community (FLC) model to build capacity for the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL) in a discipline where SoTL is emerging as a scholarly enterprise. A preliminary analysis of FLC participant surveys indicates that this FLC model was successful in SoTL professional development and fostering a strong sense of community. This FLC model also prepared participants to serve as SoTL leaders and advocates in our field. In response to the COVID-19 global pandemic, the FLC collaboratively developed and implemented a survey for instructors and students about the shift to remote teaching/learning. Survey results were disseminated at the 2021 LSA Annual Meeting and in the accompanying proceedings, and were used to develop an online resource for scholarly teaching. Additionally, multiple FLC participants published and presented on SoTL-related projects, one FLC participant was invited to author a book on pedagogy in their sub-discipline; two FLC participants were invited to give pedagogical talks at their institutions; and our graduate student associate established a SoTL FLC for fellow graduate students at his institution.

This project allowed the LSA to elevate and showcase SoTL in the discipline of linguistics, signal its commitment to scholarly teaching, and recognize the value of SoTL contributions. Through ongoing conversation and critical reflection, the FLC committed to centering justice, equity, diversity and inclusion not just in our own teaching but also in future SoTL activities and programming sponsored by the LSA. FLC members worked with LSA leadership to publish a statement on the Scholarly Merit of the Scholarship of Teaching and Learning (SoTL) to support the professional advancement of linguists who are scholars of teaching.
